item.title: Photos: Backstage With Teyana Taylor, Owen Cooper and More Golden Globe Winners
item.description: Rose Byrne, Owen Cooper, Seth Rogen, Teyana Taylor and other award winners in the spotlight.
item.dc:creator: Chantal Anderson
item.media:credit: Chantal Anderson for The New York Times

item.title: Nikki Glaser’s Monologue, Teyana Taylor’s Speech and Other Moments From the 2026 Globes
item.description: Nikki Glaser returned as host and killed, while Teyana Taylor delivered the speech of the night. Then there were those awful production choices.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman
item.media:credit: Kevork Djansezian/CBS Broadcasting, via Associated Press
item.media:description: As Nikki Glaser served as Golden Globes host on Sunday night, her previous experience in the role paid off.

item.title: Golden Globes Winners 2026: Full List Including ’One Battle After Another,’ ‘Sinners’ and ‘Good Hang With Amy Poehler’
item.description: The winning films, TV shows, actors and production teams at the 2026 Golden Globe Awards.
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Rich Polk/Penske Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Chloé Zhao, center, accepting the award for best motion picture drama: “Hamnet.”

item.title: How Wagner Moura Stayed True to Himself and Earned a Golden Globe Nomination
item.description: The Brazilian star of “The Secret Agent” is a major Oscar contender, though some at home turned against him for criticizing the right-wing government.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan and Sela Shiloni

item.title: Who Should the Oscar Nominees Be? Our Movie Critics Pick.
item.description: Here’s who our film critics Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson think voters should pick.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis and Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: Golden Globes 2026 Photos: Stars of ‘Hamnet,’ ‘One Battle After Another’ and More
item.description: Our photographer is capturing behind-the-scenes moments with stars at Sunday night’s awards show.
item.dc:creator: Sinna Nasseri
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times

item.title: Unpacking ‘People We Meet on Vacation’ with Emily Henry, Emily Bader and Tom Blyth
item.description: The author and the actors Emily Bader and Tom Blyth explain why the movie differs from the novel and raise the possibility of spinoffs.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer and Jennelle Fong
item.media:description: Henry said a lot of the actor casting suggestions gave her pause. “After Bader and Blyth were cast, she said, “that’s when I was like, ‘It’s going to be OK.’”

item.title: Josh O’Connor’s Masterly 2025 Performances: ‘Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery’ and More
item.description: The star’s nuance and emotional power, along with his natural charisma, quietly enriched a quartet of movies in 2025.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.category: Wake Up Dead Man: A Knives Out Mystery (Movie)

item.title: Paul Haggis Reaches $2 Million Settlement After 2022 Rape Verdict
item.description: A judge had ordered the Oscar-winning filmmaker to pay at least $7.5 million to a former film-industry publicist after a civil jury found him liable for raping her.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Tiziana Fabi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Paul Haggis, who won two Oscars for “Crash” (2004), had maintained that the sexual encounter was consensual.

item.title: Adrien Brody and Tessa Thompson to Star in ‘Fear of 13’ on Broadway
item.description: The play, about a man who spends decades on death row before being exonerated by DNA evidence, will have a 16-week run this spring.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: From left: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters; Caroline Brehman/Reuters
item.media:description: “The Fear of 13,” featuring Adrien Brody and Tessa Thompson, will begin previews March 19 at the James Earl Jones Theater.

item.title: Ricky Gervais’s Golden Globe Win for His Stand-Up Special Sends a Bad Message
item.description: That “Ricky Gervais: Mortality” won for best comedy sends a message about the lack of respect given to stand-up.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman

item.title: Follow Ian McKellen Into the Mixed Reality Future in ‘An Ark’
item.description: Audiences can embark on a very different type of theatrical experience in a new play at the Shed, blending the physical world with digital content.
item.dc:creator: Roslyn Sulcas

item.title: Golden Globe Awards 2026: Best Looks From Teyana Taylor, Jennifer Lawrence and More
item.description: Sheer gowns, slouchy tuxedos, chunky-soled boots and more.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Daniel Cole/Reuters
item.media:description: Teyana Taylor’s gown had cutouts that showed off some of her chest (and some of her backside).

item.title: ‘Hamnet’ Wins Golden Globe for Best Drama
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Agata Grzybowska/Focus Features, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jessie Buckley, left, and Paul Mescal in a scene from “Hamnet.”

item.title: ‘One Battle After Another’ Wins Golden Globe for Best Comedy
item.description: The victory cements the film’s front-runner status heading into the Oscars.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Pictures, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Leonardo DiCaprio as the former radical Bob in “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: Jessie Buckley Wins Golden Globe for ‘Hamnet’ as Best Actress, Motion Picture Drama
item.description: In her first nomination, Buckley won for her portrayal of Agnes, William Shakespeare’s grieving wife in the drama “Hamnet.”
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:credit: Agata Grzybowska/Focus Features, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Jessie Buckley, center, in a scene from “Hamnet.”

item.title: ‘Adolescence’ Wins Golden Globe for Best Limited Series, Marking a Triumph for Owen Cooper
item.description: Netflix’s harrowing series about a 13-year-old British boy accused of killing a girl in his school became an immediate global hit last year.
item.dc:creator: Michaela Towfighi

item.title: Timothée Chalamet Wins Best Actor at the Golden Globes for ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: The actor won for his role in “Marty Supreme.” After five Golden Globe nominations, this is Chalamet’s first win.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Morgan

item.title: Where’s the best original score award? Not on the telecast.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Globe for best score will be handed out at the ceremony but not be televised.

item.title: Jean Smart, Mark Ruffalo and Natasha Lyonne Wear Anti-ICE Pins at 2026 Golden Globes
item.description: Mark Ruffalo, Wanda Sykes, Natasha Lyonne and Jean Smart were among the celebrities taking part in the campaign.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mark Ruffalo wearing a “Be Good” pin on the red carpet.

item.title: Who will be the big winners tonight? Here’s what to expect.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene at a preview event for the Golden Globes, being held Sunday at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Here’s how to watch the Globes tonight.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: A Russian Videographer Reveals How Putin Shapes the Next Generation
item.description: Pavel Talankin was a school events coordinator and videographer. When Russia overhauled the curriculum to make students into patriotic soldiers, he kept his camera rolling. The footage became a film that is shortlisted for an Oscar.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Sasha Maslov for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m just standing there filming and I understand that what’s getting into the camera isn’t just a lesson, but history,” Pavel Talankin said.

item.title: How to Watch the Golden Globes 2026: Date, Time and Streaming
item.description: Nikki Glaser is back as host, there’s a new podcast category and “One Battle After Another” looks to have a big night.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: If I Had Legs I'd Kick You (Movie)

item.title: Golden Globes 2026: What to Expect From Sunday’s Awards Ceremony
item.description: Keep an eye on “One Battle After Another,” which is likely to dominate, and on the speeches. A particularly memorable one could be an Oscar lifeline.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene at a preview event for the Golden Globes, being held Sunday at the Beverly Hilton in Beverly Hills.

item.title: Bahram Beyzaie, Filmmaker Who Led Iran’s New Wave, Dies at 87
item.description: Despite a ceaseless battle against government censors, he was celebrated as one of his country’s greatest auteurs, winning praise from luminaries like Martin Scorsese.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams

item.title: Producers Guild Nominations Strengthen Oscar Odds for Five Films
item.description: “One Battle After Another,” “Sinners,” “Hamnet,” “Frankenstein” and “Marty Supreme” have now been recognized by all three major guilds.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba Infinity Castle (Movie)

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include an elliptical Mexican anthology film, an experimental biopic of the writer Suzanne Césaire and more.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish

item.title: 8 New Movies Our Critics Are Talking About This Week
item.description: Whether you’re a casual moviegoer or an avid buff, our reviewers think these films are worth knowing about.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Will Arnett, Laura Dern and Bradley Cooper: 3 Friends Walk Into a Comedy Club
item.description: In many ways, their new relationship tale, “Is This Thing On?,” relies on their shared history over 25 years.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik and Sam Hellmann
item.media:description: Will Arnett, left, Bradley Cooper and Laura Dern mined their shared histories and foibles.

item.title: How a Travel Writer Became Timothée Chalamet’s Ping-Pong Nemesis in ‘Marty Supreme’
item.description: For Pico Iyer, making his acting debut in the hit movie “Marty Supreme” was the latest journey in a life full of unexpected voyages.
item.dc:creator: Pico Iyer

item.title: 5 Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a film sequel to a beloved franchise and a documentary about the plight of polar bears.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman
item.category: Diary of a Wimpy Kid: The Last Straw (Movie)

item.title: ‘Primate’ Review: Going Ape
item.description: This blood-splattered survival film about a rabies-infected chimpanzee is powered by unabashedly simple pleasures.
item.dc:creator: Brandon Yu

item.title: Hailee Steinfeld on ‘Sinners’ and What the Movie Taught Her
item.description: For the Ryan Coogler-directed vampire tale, “this character is what pushed me to sort of truly live in myself,” the actress said.
item.dc:creator: Brian Josephs
item.media:credit: Warner Bros.
item.media:description: Hailee Steinfeld as Mary in “Sinners.” “This movie was a door I’ve been knocking on for a while,” she said.

item.title: Riding the Roller Coaster Beat
item.description: Mekado Murphy, the assistant film editor for The New York Times, moonlights as the newspaper’s unofficial roller coaster correspondent.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: ‘Bug’ Review: Carrie Coon Is Superb in an American Gothic Tale
item.description: Tracy Letts’s eerily topical, decades-old play about a woman’s descent into a world of conspiracy theories makes its nerve-rattling Broadway debut.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrie Coon and Namir Smallwood in Tracy Letts’s stylistically slippery “Bug” at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: ‘People We Meet on Vacation’ Review: When Stuffy Met Silly
item.description: Love grows between a restless travel writer and a contented homebody in this occasionally cute, instantly forgettable romantic comedy.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis

item.title: Amos Poe, New York’s No Wave Film Pioneer, Dies at 76
item.description: He documented the punk and post-punk music scene in the East Village, leading an independent film movement that was proudly unprofessional.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green

item.title: 2026 Directors Guild Nominations: ‘One Battle,’ ‘Sinners’
item.description: The films of Paul Thomas Anderson and Ryan Coogler have been competing all season. Also in the running are Guillermo del Toro, Josh Safdie and Chloé Zhao.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: ‘Magellan’ Review: The Beauty and the Bloodshed of a Smaller World
item.description: Gael García Bernal plays the explorer Ferdinand Magellan in Lav Diaz’s portrait of a brutal adventurer and his travels across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis

item.title: ‘Greenland 2: Migration’ Review: The New World
item.description: Gerard Butler returns for more earthshaking action in this crowd-pleasing postapocalyptic thriller.
item.dc:creator: Robert Daniels

item.title: The Movie That Inspired Michael Mann to Direct
item.description: “The Joyless Street” is among the most chopped-up films of the silent era. A restoration at MoMA’s To Save and Project series proves eye-opening.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘Young Mothers’ Review: Teen Parents, Breaking Cycles
item.description: The Dardenne brothers’ latest film is a tender portrait of four teenage moms in a Belgian maternity shelter.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson

item.title: ‘OBEX’ Review: An Analog Nightmare
item.description: In this indie oddity boasting visceral D.I.Y. effects, a gentle loner enters the world of a video game to save his beloved dog.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza

item.title: ‘My Neighbor Adolf’ Review: The Nazi Next Door
item.description: The actors Udo Kier and David Hayman square off in this domestic drama where a man is convinced that his neighbor is Adolf Hitler.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny

item.title: ‘Holding Liat’ Review: Hostage Situation
item.description: This unpredictable documentary follows a man and his family as they wait for news of his daughter and her husband, who were kidnapped in the Hamas-led Oct. 7, 2023, attacks on Israel.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold
item.media:credit: Meridian Hill Pictures
item.media:description: Yehuda Beinin, left, and Tal Beinin in the documentary “Holding Liat.”

item.title: Can Shawn Levy Resuscitate ‘Star Wars’?
item.description: Lucasfilm hopes that Shawn Levy, who made “Deadpool and Wolverine” and helped make “Stranger Things,” can bring that same touch. The key may be his inner child.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:credit: Max Miechowski for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I’m the guy the studios call when they want someone they know will take their investment seriously and deliver responsibly,” Shawn Levy said.

item.title: ‘Dead Man’s Wire’ Review: When the Action Is Razor Thin
item.description: Dramatizing an odd news item from 1977, Gus Van Sant’s crime film isn’t crazy enough.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg

item.title: ‘All That’s Left of You’ Review: Hearts, Minds, History
item.description: The Palestinian American director Cherien Dabis offers eloquent context with her generational drama about Palestinian men.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy

item.title: Interview: Tilda Swinton on Her Favorite Books and Favorite Collaborators
item.description: Starring in the 1992 film adaptation helped launch an eclectic career. “Ongoing” is the book that accompanies a retrospective on her work.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Clarke

item.title: Arthur Cohn, Film Producer With an Oscar-Winning Touch, Dies at 98
item.description: Six of his movies received Academy Awards, including the Italian drama “The Garden of the Finzi-Continis” and the trade-union strike documentary “American Dream.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:credit: Martin Ruetschi/Keystone, via Redux Pictures
item.media:description: Arthur Cohn in his office in Basel, Switzerland, in 2000. “I search for projects that are out of the ordinary, enriching and apt to be remembered for a long time,” he said.

item.title: 2026 SAG Actor Award Nominations List: ‘One Battle’ and ‘Sinners’ Lead
item.description: Timothée Chalamet and Ariana Grande also scored nods. Cynthia Erivo and the stars of “Jay Kelly” were left out.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: Nick Reiner’s Lawyer, Alan Jackson, Removes Himself From Murder Case
item.description: Mr. Reiner, who is charged with killing his parents, will now be represented by a public defender. His arraignment has been rescheduled for next month.
item.dc:creator: Tim Arango and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Richard Shotwell/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nick Reiner was charged with two counts of first-degree murder. If he is convicted, he could face a life sentence without parole or the death penalty.

item.title: Can Timothée Chalamet Break This Oscar Curse?
item.description: The best actor Oscar almost never goes to young men, though the 30-year-old has his best chance yet with “Marty Supreme.”
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: The Cast and Creators of ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ on How the Movie Came to Be
item.description: As the filmmakers, songwriters and actors tell it, their “wackadoo” concept evolved over nine years and eight versions of “Golden” into a global phenomenon.
item.dc:creator: Melena Ryzik

item.title: To Be or Not to Be: That Is the Question Filmmakers Can’t Resist
item.description: The Shakespearean monologue that is featured twice in “Hamnet” has long informed the movies, often in surprising ways that can make us rethink the words.
item.dc:creator: Alissa Wilkinson
item.category: Star Trek VI: The Undiscovered Country (Movie)
To Be or Not to Be (Movie)
